items.title: How to solve the CSS layout and source order disconnect?
items.content:
#‚Äã589 ‚Äî April 19, 2023 | Read on the web

It's Time to Learn OKLCH Color ‚Äî Feeling a bit overwhelmed by all the developments happening in CSS lately involving color? We‚Äôve got several new options to consider such as hwb(), lab(), lch(), oklab(), and oklch() ‚Äî here Keith makes the case for OKLCH and how to get started using¬†it.

Keith J. Grant

Solving the CSS Layout and Source Order Disconnect ‚Äî The CSS Working Group is seeking feedback on a proposed solution for ‚Äúthe problem of layout methods arranging items in an order that is disconnected from the source of the document‚Äù. This post explains the issue, the suggested fix, and invites your¬†thoughts.

Rachel Andrew (Chrome Developers)

New Course by Kyle Simpson: Practical Problem Solving with Algorithms ‚Äî Walk through four fun challenges with Kyle in this new video course. You'll learn how to apply algorithms with techniques like recursion, traversals, and acyclic paths, cover memoization to avoid garbage collection, and come away writing more performant¬†code.

Frontend Masters sponsor

What's New in WCAG 2.2? ‚Äî Notes on what‚Äôs changing in the upcoming 2.2 accessibility guidelines from WCAG expert Alaina¬†Birney.

Seth Wilson & Alaina Birney

Integrating React Flow and the Web Audio API ‚Äî React Flow is a component for building node-based editors and interactive diagrams, which makes it well suited for building audio signal chains. There‚Äôs a lot of depth here, some nice examples, and these techniques could prove useful for a lot of other use¬†cases.

Hayleigh Thompson

‚ö°Ô∏è IN BRIEF

  • Mozilla is allegedly working on a new usability feature for Firefox that may reject cookie related prompts automatically.

  • Adriana Jara runs through what's new in Chrome 112, including the much heralded support for CSS rule nesting.

  • Version 6.0 of the Vivaldi browser is out now, with new tab management and workspace features.

üìô Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Recreating a 'Mouse-Aware' Text Effect ‚Äî The author was ‚Äúso impressed with the design‚Äù of the Creative South 2023 site that she wanted to recreate the neat ‚Äò3D‚Äô effect seen on the title text. Here‚Äôs a quick look at how she did it, complete with code and a¬†demo.

Rach Smith

Designing for Color Blindness ‚Äî A few real-world examples of what a person with color-blindness sees. ‚ÄúLiving with colorblindness feels like you‚Äôre constantly being pranked by the world in subtle, irritating¬†ways‚Äù.

Andy Baio

Build and Deploy ‚Äò23: May 3rd - Save the Date ‚Äî The ultimate CI/CD virtual conference - best practices and end-user success stories from DevOps experts. Plus, a keynote from Emily Freeman, author of DevOps for¬†Dummies.

Codefresh sponsor

Optimizing Resource Loading with the Fetch Priority API ‚Äî Fetch Priority (previously known as Priority Hints) indicates the relative priority of resources to the browser ‚Äî it can enable optimal loading and improve Core Web Vitals. It‚Äôs currently supported in Chrome and¬†Edge.

web.dev

Interaction to Next Paint (INP): What Is It and How to Improve It ‚Äî Page responsiveness is critical to a good user experience on the web. This post shares how best to measure and improve it with the Interaction to Next Paint¬†metric.

Karolina Szczur

Passkeys: What The Heck and Why? ‚Äî The author has been studying up and experimenting with passkeys ‚Äî and the associated WebAuthn API that they are built on top of. This is a solid primer on an increasingly popular security¬†option.

Neal Fennimore

‚ñ∂¬†¬†Reducing Layout Shifts with Custom Fallback Fonts
Brian Ramirez

Improve Largest Contentful Paint (LCP) by Removing Image Transitions
Michael Gooding (Shopify)

'I Made My Blog Solar-Powered, Then Things Escalated'
Louwrentius

üîß Code, Tools & Resources

Iconoir: 1300+ Open Source SVG Icons ‚Äî A vast array of clean and simple icons, complete with ways to quickly integrate them into React, React Native, Figma, and other apps ‚Äì or just using CSS, if you¬†prefer.

Luca Burgio

Open-Source JavaScript Form Libraries: Build Multiple Forms¬†In‚ÄëHouse ‚Äî Make form creation secure and easy with a self-hosted no-code form editor. Store survey data with no third-party¬†involved.

SurveyJS sponsor

Tailwind Animations: A Small Library of CSS Animations Built with Tailwind ‚Äî There are animated GIFs showing off the animations here.

Canopas

Skeleton: A Toolkit for Building Reactive and Accessible UIs with Svelte & Tailwind ‚Äî A cool feature of the home page is that you can try out the different built-in themes for the library, plus dark and light modes, using a drop-down at the¬†top.

Skeleton Labs

favicon.software: Quickly Generate Favicons and HTML from a Logo or Other Image ‚Äî Supports just about any image format and all conversion happens in the¬†browser.

favicon.software

Color Contrast Checker: Analyzer and Color Suggestions ‚Äî A straightforward tool for checking the contrast between colors using WCAG or APCA. It also offers up suggestions for better colors when¬†needed.

Polypane

Reveal.js 4.5: An HTML Presentation Framework ‚Äî Brings elegant presentations to anyone with a Web browser. v4.5 was just released with support for jumping to specific slides, a few new themes, and with live reload working with files in¬†subfolders.

Hakim El Hattab

Easy Email: A Drag-and-Drop Email Editor for React ‚Äî Generates code through drag-and-drop editing and by employing the MJML responsive email¬†framework.

Zalify

items.title: How WebAssembly is pushing the Web forward
items.content:
#‚Äã587 ‚Äî April 5, 2023 | Read on the web

Getting PWAs in App Stores with PWABuilder ‚Äî Thomas Steiner demonstrates how PWABuilder makes it possible to submit Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) to app stores like those provided by Google, Apple, and¬†Microsoft.

Thomas Steiner (Google)

CSS Masking ‚Äî A deep dive into using CSS to apply masks to images, covering how it works, along with a few use cases and accompanying¬†examples.

Ahmad Shadeed

Everything You Need to Know About Video Storage APIs ‚Äî A technical overview of video storage APIs, including how they work, the benefits of using them, and how to implement one for your video¬†needs.

ImageKit sponsor

How WebAssembly is Accelerating New Web Functionality ‚Äî WebAssembly is a portable bytecode format that‚Äôs now broadly supported and allows developers to create new capabilities and functionality on the web. It doesn‚Äôt necessarily replace JavaScript, but extends its¬†capabilities.

Thomas Nattestad (Google)

Mullvad and Tor Team Up to Release Privacy-Focused¬†Browser ‚Äî Mullvad is a popular privacy-focused VPN service and they‚Äôve teamed up with the Tor Project to unveil a privacy-focused web browser designed to minimize the impact of tracking and fingerprinting. ‚ÄúYou could say it‚Äôs a Tor Browser to use without the Tor Network.‚Äù As with Tor, it‚Äôs a modified version of Firefox under the¬†hood.

Mullvad

‚ö°Ô∏è IN BRIEF

  • A look at what's new in Chrome 112, incuding support for CSS style nesting.

  • Oliver Dunk of the Chrome Extensions Team has posted an update on the Manifest V2 to Manifest V3 transition ‚Äì it's taking longer than expected so Manifest V2 isn't disappearing any time soon.

  • Wes Bos quickly demonstrates what you can do with CSS color functions in a 1-minute YouTube short.

  • An interview with the creator of CSS, H√•kon Wium Lie.

  • Over on Twitter, üê¶ Stefan Judis notes that Firefox Nightly is the first browser shipping support for @media (scripting: none) to detect disabled JavaScript in CSS.

  • After years of work, Firefox no longer uses any XUL layouts. XUL (XML User Interface Language) was once the bedrock of Mozilla software like Firefox, but has gradually been replaced.

  • On Windows, the latest Firefox now allows users to control which third party DLLs are allowed to load into Firefox processes.

üìô Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Are Safari Releases Causing 'Development Hell'? ‚Äî Covers the troubles one team went through with the recent feature-packed Safari 16.4 release, highlighting the ‚Äústress and disruption it caused‚Äù, and why the developer believes it amounts to ‚ÄúApple having a policy of negligence towards developers‚Äù. Harsh words, but challenges other developers might sympathize¬†with.

Ashley Gullen

What are Source Maps? ‚Äî Learn how source maps can help you debug your original code instead of what was actually deployed after a build¬†process.

Sofia Emelianova (Chrome Developers)

React Authentication, Simplified ‚Äî In this article, we lay out a new approach to authentication (plus access control & SSO) in React¬†applications.

Userfront sponsor

A CSS Selector to Highlight Clickable Elements ‚Äî An interesting, if slightly convoluted, snippet.

Seb De Deyne

‚ñ∂¬†¬†Learn HTML5 and CSS3 from Scratch ‚Äî This 11 hour epic probably isn‚Äôt for you but given it‚Äôs on YouTube, it could be handy for anyone you know who wants to learn¬†HTML.

John Smilga

üîß Code, Tools & Resources

Framework7 8.0: Build iOS, Android and Desktop Apps with¬†HTML ‚Äî An open source framework for building full-featured iOS, Android and Desktop apps with Web technologies, complete with an ecosystem of plugins and tools and the ability to hook into existing front-end¬†frameworks.

Framework7

Simple Icons: 2444 Free SVG Icons for Popular Brands ‚Äî This project that we link to every year or two continues to go from strength to¬†strength.

Simple Icons

StatiCrypt 3: Password Protect a Static HTML Page ‚Äî We first linked this a few weeks ago, but it has since had a major release with lots of cleanups and a switch to using the more secure WebCrypto engine. Live¬†demo.

Robin Moisson

How eBay Made Its New Accessibility Tool (And Made It Available to¬†All) ‚Äî Several eBay teams worked together to create a Figma plug-in that makes it easy to include accessibility in a design right from the¬†start.

Dan Nosowitz (eBay)

Ellegant CSS Framework ‚Äî Aims to provide user interaction (toggles, switches, modals, menus, etc.) with very little or no JavaScript at¬†all.

Lucas Leal

Eruda 3.0: A Console for Mobile Browsers ‚Äî If you‚Äôre in a situation where you have no access to DevTools, you can add Eruda to your page and it provides a sort of virtual devtools you can use from any browser, including on¬†mobile.

LiriLiri

Jampack: A Post-Processing Tool to Optimize Static¬†Websites ‚Äî Similar to a bundler or build tool, with features like image optimization, asset compression, and some code auto-fixes ‚Äî all amounting to strong Core Web Vitals¬†scores.

divRIOTS

items.title: Safari adds over 100 new features
items.content:
#‚Äã586 ‚Äî March 29, 2023 | Read on the web

WebKit Features in Safari 16.4 ‚Äî This is a mammoth release, adding 135(!) new features including support for Web Push, a slew of new CSS properties (including margin-trim), Declarative Shadow DOM support, iframe lazy-loading support, devtool changes, and the typical bug fixes. WebKit team member Jen Simmons said:

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to express just how massive a release Safari 16.4 is for web developers. Last night, I was reading replies web developers posted on Twitter back in 2021, when I asked what developers need most from WebKit ‚Äî and the vast majority of things you asked for have now shipped.‚Äù
Plenty of progress has been made, so it's well worth checking out to bring yourself up to speed on what‚Äôs¬†new.
  • Safari 16.4 Release Notes
    ‚Ü≥ The full, formal release notes outlining what's new in bulletpoint¬†form.

What We Can All Learn from Web Performance¬†Leaders ‚Äî Case studies from companies like Airbnb, Pinterest, BBC, Zillow, Casper, Shopify, and Leroy Merlin. Learn how they speed up their sites, use performance budgets, create a culture of performance, and measure the impact of site speed on their¬†business.

SpeedCurve sponsor

Visually Hidden Content is a 'Hack' That Needs to Be Resolved, Not Enshrined ‚Äî In issue 583 we shared Ben Myers piece on why he believes the web needs a native .visually-hidden HTML/CSS technique. Here, Scott shares his take: ‚Äúwhile there is a common ruleset for visually hiding content, codifying that to me seems more of a silent acknowledgement that a hack is the best we can do. I don‚Äôt agree. The web should be better than¬†that‚Äù.

Scott O'Hara

The Ultimate Guide to Image Optimization ‚Äî Image optimization is the web performance ‚Äòlowest hanging fruit‚Äô. Here‚Äôs a sound look at how to optimise imagery without sacrificing its¬†quality.

Karolina Szczur

‚ö°Ô∏è IN BRIEF

  • Good news!¬†Push notifications are now supported cross-browser in the three most common browser engines.

  • The first Safari 16.5 Beta is out now with support for CSS Nesting.

  • Did you know some home appliances have a 'Sabbath mode'? Eric Bailey explains, and notes how such a practice may translate to digital experiences.

  • Back in October of last year we shared how Manuel Matuzoviƒá was embarking on a journey to learn modern CSS bits over the course of 100 days. That journey came to an end last month.

üìô Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Improving CSS Shapes with Trigonometric Functions ‚Äî This is an excellent dive into how we can use trigonometric functions to simplify how we approach making regular polygons and how to use these new CSS powers to build even more complex shapes by approximating curves. Lots of code examples and demos here¬†too.

Dan Wilson

‚è±Ô∏è A few weeks back we shared this fun look at using trigonometry functions to create a working clock.

Health Benefits of Browser Diversity ‚Äî With rumblings that Apple may be opening up the iOS ecosystem to other browser engines, and the positive progress the WebKit team are taking with Safari (see above), Tim is optimistic that ‚Äúa pivot in strategy from Apple could open up so many doors to a healthier¬†web‚Äù.

Tim Kadlec

Yes-Code Automation with Retool Workflows ‚Äî A fastest way to create intelligent, code-first integrations across your entire data stack. No extra infra¬†required.

Retool sponsor

CSS-Only Widgets Are Inaccessible ‚Äî Notes that any claim that a CSS-only interactive widget is accessible ‚Äúis probably¬†wrong‚Äù.

Adrian Roselli

File Uploads for the Web: Uploading Files with HTML ‚Äî The first post in a series all about uploading files to the web ‚Äî this post, covers the steps needed to upload files using only HTML. The second covers JavaScript. Austin tells us more are on the way, looking at architecture planning, performance, security, and¬†more.

Austin Gil

Why APCA as a New Contrast Method? ‚Äî This document isn‚Äôt new, but it popped up on our radar this week ‚Äî it‚Äôs a solid intro/overview of the Accessible Perceptual Contrast Algorithm, a proposed solution for handling readability contrast in WCAG 3.0 and beyond. Related¬†repo.

Myndex

The Role of X-Height in Typefaces
Dan Hollick

Stefan Judis

It‚Äôs About Time CAPTCHAs Become Accessible
Camryn Manker

16 Little UI Design Rules That Make a Big Impact
Adham Dannaway

Evan Wallace

Accessibility Checker: Scan Any Site for ADA & WCAG¬†Compliance ‚Äî A nicely designed tool that provides clear instructions on fixing accessibility errors and warnings. Enter a URL and get a¬†report.

Accessibility Checker

Don‚Äôt Let Your Issue Tracker Be a Four-Letter Word. Use¬†Shortcut

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse‚Ä§io) sponsor

Font-Awesome 6.4.0 Released ‚Äî This version of "the Internet's icon library" adds an all new ‚ÄòSharp Light‚Äô icon style (pictured), along with a slew of new icons (including a¬†dinosaur). The free library now sits at over 2,000 icons, and balloons to a massive 25,000+ for paid users. Changelog.

Font Awesome

IMG Quest: An Open-Source API to Generate Open Graph Images ‚Äî Add an image URL, then specify the style you want the image to appear with, along with foreground and background colors, then use the generated URL in your meta¬†tags.

Bright: A React Server Component for Syntax Highlighting ‚Äî Customizable and includes all of VS Code‚Äôs syntax highlighting themes, some of which are demonstrated on the¬†page.
